In terms of harsh legislations there are many more. 

So when political leaders say they condemn the emergency, they should be asked if they will undo these changes.

One can clearly understand TN that is now is far different from the province that was in Aug 15th, 1947. The union is an indestructible part but at the same time the states enjoy clearly constitutional powers as mentioned in the state list & shared powers under concurrent list.

Bringing back education from Concurrent list to State is the only solution to Ban NEET!

 #DMKbetrayedAnitha

2. State List- 66 subjects
3. Concurrent List- 47 subjects

What is the State list?

State List is a part of the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution of India which enumerates exclusive matters on which a State legislature can make laws and have control upon. 

The other two lists are- List I (Union List) & List III (Concurrent List)

Before 1954, only state govt. had powers to make law related to agriculture. But, in 1954, Nehru chacha did an amendment which gave powers to centre too to make agriculture related law, refers to the entry on 33 of concurrent list. https://t.co/hFNGeGDMH5

In simple words, there are few sections where only state govt. can make law (state list) & there are few sections where only Centre can make law (union list). However, there are few section where both can make law (concurrent list), refers to the 7th schedule of our constitution. https://t.co/QhwmFbATvh

Executive list: Federal government

Residual list: Not attended to, usually left to state

Evolution of Education Policy

* University Education Commission (1948-49)

* Secondary Education Commission (1952-53)

* Education Commission (1964-66) (D.S.Kothari)

Centralisation started during Emergency

Many which were in concurrent list were moved to central list, many from state list were moved to concurrent list

States have lost power over

Education
Taxes (GST)
Electricity
Water JALboard
Administration
PDS (initiated)
No #federalism

+ a range of other directions. The National Disaster Management Act is a law passed by the Union Parliament, mostly under the concurrent list and residuary powers of the Union under the Constitution. It cannot be used to legally compel state govts on issues under the states list.
